article.name: Whitelist by Email Header in Google Workspace
article.title: Whitelist by Email Header in Google Workspace
article.body:
Note: Due to upcoming changes from Google, we recommend using Direct Message Injection (DMI) as your default whitelisting configuration. For more information about these changes, see Google's Gmail updates.

If your organization uses Google Workspace, you can whitelist by email header. To whitelist by email header, you'll need to apply a Content Compliance rule to emails that contain KnowBe4's email header. This rule will allow our simulated phishing emails to be delivered to your user's inboxes.

Important: To ensure that your user opens are being tracked properly, you may need to add our phish link domains to your Googe Workspace’s Image URL proxy allowlist. For more information, see Google’s Set up an image URL proxy allowlist article.
Note:We only recommend this setting if your organization uses a cloud-based spam filter for Google Workspace. If you're using Google Workspace for your email without an additional spam filter, you can instead whitelist by IP address. For more information, see our Whitelisting by IP Address in Google Workspace article. You will also need to whitelist KnowBe4's IP addresses or hostnames in your cloud-based spam filter to make sure emails are delivered successfully.
Note:This article reflects our most up-to-date best practices for whitelisting with your provider. Please be aware that your mail service provider may make changes to how their systems analyze our emails at any time. If you are having issues whitelisting using the procedure below, contact our support team.

To whitelist KnowBe4 by email header in Google Workspace, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Google Admin account and click Apps.
  2. Click Google Workspace.
  3. In the Showing status for apps in all organizational units area, click Gmail.
  4. In the Gmail area, click Compliance.
  5. Navigate to the Content Compliance section.
  6. Click Add a rule.
    Note:If you have previously created a Content Compliance rule, this option will be called Add Another Rule.
  7. In the Email messages to affect field, select the Inbound checkbox and the Internal - receiving check box.
  8. Under the Expressions tab, click the first drop-down menu.
  9. From the first drop-down menu, select if ANY of the following match the message.
  10. Click Add.
  11. Undate the settings in the Add expressions that describe the content you want to search for in each message area. For more information about these settings, see the screenshot and list below:
    1. From the first drop-down menu, select Advanced content match.
    2. In Location field, select Full headers.
    3. In the Match type field, select Contains text.
    4. In the Content field, enter the header text. The default KnowBe4 header is "X-PHISHTEST".
      Note:For enhanced security, we recommend that you change the default header to a custom header or header token. You can change the header settings in your KSAT Account Settings. For more information, see our Account Settings Guide article.
    5. Click SAVE.
  12. In the If the above expressions match, do the following field, select the Bypass spam filter for this message check box under Spam.

We recommend setting up a test phishing campaign for yourself or a small group of users. This test phishing campaign can help ensure that your whitelisting was successful. The setting may take up to an hour to deploy to all users so wait at least an hour before testing. If you experience whitelisting issues after following the steps above, contact our support team.

Note:If your organization uses Google Workspace, you’ll also need to disable the return-path header in your KSAT Account Settings before sending phishing tests. For more information, see our How to Change the Return-Path Header in Your Account Settings.
Tip: To ensure that you have whitelisted correctly, see our How to Verify You Have Whitelisted KnowBe4 Correctly article.

images.alt:
This image displays the primary dashboard of the **Google Admin Console**.

**Header and Navigation:**
The top blue bar features the "Google Admin" logo, a hamburger menu icon (navigation), and a search bar containing the placeholder text: "Search for users, groups or settings". Utility icons on the right include history/notifications, a question mark (Help), and the Google apps grid.

**Context and Content:**
The main content area is titled "Admin Console" and consists of a grid layout of administrative modules, each featuring an icon, a bold title, and a descriptive subtitle.

**Featured Modules (Top to Bottom, Left to Right):**

| Title | Subtitle |
| :--- | :--- |
| **Dashboard** | See relevant insights about your organization |
| **Users** | Add or manage users |
| **Groups** | Create groups and mailing lists |
| **Organizational units** | Add, remove, rename, move or search for an organizational unit |
| **Buildings and resources** | Manage and monitor buildings, rooms and resources |
| **Devices** | Secure corporate data on devices |
| **Apps** (Highlighted) | Manage apps and their settings (Visually emphasized by an orange border) |
| **Security** | Configure security settings |
| **Reports** | Monitor usage across your organization |
| **Billing** | Manage subscriptions and billing |
| **Company profile** | Update information about your company |
| **Admin roles** | Manage administrative roles |
| **Domains** | Manage your domains |
| **Data migration** | Manage migration |
| **Rules** | Creates rules to better manage your organization |
| **Support** | Talk to our support team |
images.context: Log in to your Google Admin account and click Apps.

images.alt:
This image displays the **Apps** management section within the **Google Admin** console, featuring a grid layout of application categories.

**1. Header and Navigation Bar (Blue):**
*   **Branding:** "Google Admin" is displayed prominently.
*   **Search:** A centralized search bar is present with the placeholder text: "Search for users, groups or settings."
*   **Utility Icons (Right):** Includes icons for History, Help, App Launcher (grid), and User Profile (initial 'C').

**2. Main Content Area (Apps Overview):**
The primary interface is titled "Apps" and presents application management categories in two rows of tiles.

**3. Application Categories (Row 1):**
*   **Google Workspace (Highlighted):** Title: Google Workspace; Description: Google Workspace Core services; Status: 14 SERVICES. This card is visually emphasized with an orange border.
*   **Additional Google services:** Title: Additional Google services; Description: Blogging, photos, video, social tools and more; Status: 58 SERVICES.
*   **Web and mobile apps:** Title: Web and mobile apps; Description: Manage SAML, Android and iOS apps; Status: 7 APPS.
*   **Google Workspace Marketplace apps:** Title: Google Workspace Marketplace apps; Description: Add and manage third party apps; Status: 4 SERVICES. Includes a visible action link: **MANAGE**.

**4. Application Categories (Row 2):**
*   **SAML apps:** Title: SAML apps; Description: Manage SSO and User Provisioning; Status: 7 SERVICES.
*   **LDAP:** Title: LDAP; Description: Add and manage LDAP clients; Status: NO CLIENTS.
*   **Password vaulted apps:** Title: Password vaulted apps; Description: Add and manage access to apps that use credentials; Status: NO SERVICES.

Click Google Workspace.

images.alt:
This image displays a configuration screen, likely from a Google Workspace (formerly G Suite) administrative console, detailing the activation status of applications across all organizational units.

**UI Structure and Header:**
*   The header text reads: "Showing status for apps in **all organizational units**."
*   A functional link/button in the top right corner is labeled: "ADD SERVICES".

**Data Grid:**
The core element is a data grid with three primary columns:
1.  **Selection:** A checkbox control precedes each service name.
2.  **Services:** Displays the application icon and name. The column header is marked "Services ↑," indicating the list is sorted alphabetically ascending by service name.
3.  **Service Status:** Displays the current operational status.

**Service Listing Details:**
The data grid lists eight services, all currently showing the same status: **ON for everyone** (displayed in green text).

| Service Icon | Service Name | Status |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| Calendar (Blue icon) | Calendar | ON for everyone |
| Cloud Search (Blue icon) | Cloud Search | ON for everyone |
| Drive and Docs (Tri-color icon) | Drive and Docs | ON for everyone |
| Gmail (Red/White envelope) | **Gmail** *(Note: This row is highlighted with an orange bounding box.)* | ON for everyone |
| Google+ (Red G+) | Google+ | ON for everyone |
| Google Hangouts (Green icon) | Google Hangouts | ON for everyone |
| Google Vault (Blue icon) | Google Vault | ON for everyone |

**Footer and Pagination:**
*   **Rows per page:** A selection control in the bottom left shows "50 ▼".
*   **Pagination:** The bottom right displays "Page 1 of 1" alongside standard navigation arrows (first, previous, next, last).
*   A light gray scrollbar is visible along the right edge, indicating a full list extends beyond the current viewport.
images.context: strong>Showing status for apps in all organizational units area, click Gmail.

images.alt:
The image displays the Google Admin console interface for configuring Gmail service settings.

**UI Context:** The blue header shows the application title, "Google Admin," and a universal search bar. Breadcrumbs indicate the navigation path: `Apps > G Suite > Settings for Gmail`.

**Service Overview:**
*   The application header identifies the service as **Gmail**.
*   Status: **ON for everyone**.
*   Three example mail URLs are listed below the status.
*   A statistic shows **1** Active users in last 7 days.
*   An action button, **EDIT SERVICE**, is located in the top right of this section.

**Configuration Settings List:** The central area lists configuration categories as links, each followed by a concise description. The visible categories include:

1.  User settings
2.  Hosts
3.  Default routing
4.  Authenticate email (DKIM)
5.  Manage quarantines
6.  Safety
7.  Setup
8.  End User Access
9.  Spam, Phishing and Malware
10. **Compliance:** (Highlighted with an orange border) Text: "Configure compliance features."
11. Routing: Text: "Configure routing features."

In the Gmail area, click Compliance.

images.alt:
The image displays the "Add setting" screen for configuring an Advanced Content Match rule within an "Edit setting" workflow.

**Context:** The current step, indicated in the gray banner, is "2. Add expressions that describe the content you want to search for in each message."

**Configuration Fields:**

*   **Field 1 (A):** Dropdown menu labeled "Advanced content match."
*   **Field 2 (B - Location):** Dropdown field labeled "Location," currently set to **"Full headers."**
*   **Field 3 (C - Match type):** Dropdown field labeled "Match type," currently set to **"Contains text."**
*   **Field 4 (D - Content):** Text input field labeled "Content," populated with the value **"X-PHISHTEST TOKEN."**

**Actions (E):** The bottom right of the screen provides two action buttons: "CANCEL" and the primary action button, **"SAVE."**
images.context:
nt Settings Guide article.

Click SAVE.

images.alt:
The image displays a configuration pane for modifying message rules, specifically detailing actions to be taken when pre-defined expressions match.

**Context and Header:**
The heading is "3. If the above expressions match, do the following." Below the heading is a dropdown menu currently displaying the selection "Modify message."

**Configuration Sections and UI Elements:**
The pane lists various message modification options, organized by category. All listed options utilize checkboxes (with the exception of the highlighted item):

*   **Headers:** Three unchecked options for adding specialized headers: "Add X-Gm-Original-To header," "Add X-Gm-Spam and X-Gm-Phishy headers," and "Add custom headers."
*   **Subject:** One unchecked option: "Prepend custom subject."
*   **Route:** One unchecked option: "Change route."
*   **Envelope recipient:** One unchecked option: "Change envelope recipient."
*   **Spam:** This section is visually highlighted by an orange bounding box. It contains one **checked** option: "**Bypass spam filter for this message**."
*   **Attachments:** One unchecked option: "Remove attachments from message."
*   **Also deliver to:** One unchecked option: "Add more recipients."
*   **Encryption (onward delivery only):**
    *   One unchecked option: "Require secure transport (TLS)."
    *   One unchecked option: "Encrypt message if not encrypted (S/MIME)."
    *   One indented, unchecked sub-option: "Bounce message if unable to sign and encrypt."

**Footer Elements:**
A link labeled "Show options" is visible at the bottom left. Action buttons "CANCEL" and "SAVE" are positioned in the bottom right corner.
images.context: , select the Bypass spam filter for this message check box under Spam.
